summary.para: Top Level Namespace for the dotNetRDF Library which embodies a simple but powerful API for manipulating RDF.
Specific Namespaces within the Hierarchy provide Parsing, Serialization and Translation functionality along with a host of related classes to support these functions.

Support for querying RDF is provided in the Query namespace which includes SPARQL Query, limited reasoning support in the Query.Inference namespace and a Pellet client in the Query.Inference.Pellet namespace.
Support for updating RDF based on the SPARQL 1.1 Update and Uniform HTTP Protocol for RDF Graph Management is provided in the Update and Update.Protocol namespaces.

For communicating with arbitrary Triple Stores we have a dedicated Storage namespace. As of this release we support the following Triple Stores:
AllegroGraph
4store
Joseki
Any Sesame HTTP Protocl compliant store
Any SPARQL Uniform HTTP Protocol for RDF Graph Management compliant stores
Talis Platform
Virtuoso
There is also support for using SQL backed stores (only recommended for small scale testing and development) and a couple of other forms of read-only store namely RDF dataset files and SPARQL query endpoints.

For those building ASP.Net based websites the Web namespace is dedicated to providing classes for integrating RDF into ASP.Net applications. If you've used dotNetRDF for ASP.Net applications prior to Version 0.3.0 please be aware that most of the existing classes were deprecated in favour of new classes which take advantage of the new Configuration API.
There is also a fairly new and experimental Ontology namespace which provides a more resource and ontology centric API for working with RDF which was introduced in the 0.2.2 release

As of the 0.3.0 release we introduced a new Configuration API which provides for encoding configuration in RDF Graphs. This configuration system has been used as part of a complete refresh of the ASP.Net support as it allows for much more expressive and flexible configurations than were previously possible. See the documentation on the main website for many detailed examples.

Currently dotNetRDF is still considered to be in Alpha, this means it may not be suitable for production scenarios and that the API is subject to change in subsequent releases should we feel it necessary. As it is an Alpha release users should be aware that the software will not be bug free. While we continually work to improve the quality of this library and to eliminate bugs as we find them we are at the same time attempting to enhance the library by adding more functionality so it is inevitable that some bugs will persist. Please help us improve this library by emailing us when you find a bug, you can use the Bug Reports list to report bugs, the Support list to ask questions and the Developer list to request new features or discuss development plans (all these are SourceForge mailing lists which require subscription).

The 0.3.x release makes very few breaking API changes compared to the 0.2.x API and it is planned that the API should continue to remain relatively stable other than the introduction of new features and the removal of the now deprecated older ASP.Net classes. Further 0.3.x releases will focus on bringing continued improvements in the ASP.Net support and increased support for reasoning.

We provide a Mono build of dotNetRDF (dotNetRDF.Mono.dll) which is currently targeted at Mono 2.6 - this port is highly experimental and has received little/no testing. There are some known incompatabilities with Mono mostly regarding the 3rd party libraries that dotNetRDF uses - Virtuoso and MySQL support is likely not to function under Mono. As far as we are aware all other features should work normally, in terms of roadmap the Mono build is not our main priority currently and we will conduct full testing of the Mono build in the future and make an announcement once we consider that build to be stable or have had time to adapt the build appropriately.

We provide a Silverlight build of dotNetRDF (dotNetRDF.Silverlight.dll) which is an experimental build which has been tested by external users but not internally as we don't do any Silverlight development currently. This build runs on Silverlight 4 and omits the following features since they can't be supported under Silverlight:

ul.li: Most of the Storage namespace and the Web namespaces
No String normalization support
No UriLoader caching support
No multi-threaded support where ReaderWriterLockSlim is used
Various writers and parsers use streaming rather than DOM based XML parsing
No support for XSL in TriX files

summary.para: Namespace for Configuration Classes which are used for dynamic loading of Configuration serialized as RDF Graphs.

As of the 0.3.0 release we introduced this new API which provides for encoding configuration in RDF Graphs. This configuration system has been used as part of a complete refresh of the ASP.Net support as it allows for much more expressive and flexible configurations than were previously possible. See the documentation on the main website for many detailed examples.
Namespace for classes related to configuring Permissions
Warning: The API here is experimental and may changed/be removed in future releases
The Ontology Namespace is based upon Jena's Ontology API and is an experimental part of the library. It allows for a more resource-centric way of manipulating RDF graphs within the dotNetRDF API.

The OntologyResource is the base class of resources and allows for the retrieval and manipulation of various common properties of a resource. More specialised classes like OntologyClass and OntologyProperty are used to work with classes and properties etc.

One key feature of this new part of the API is the ReasonerGraph which allows you to wrap an existing Graph with a reasoner to get a unified view over the original Triples and materialised inferences without modifying your original Graph.
Namespace for Parsing Classes and variety of supporting Classes.
Classes here are primarily implementations of ITokeniser and IRdfReader with some implementations of IStoreReader and a few other specialised classes.
Has child namespaces Events and Tokens for supporting Event and Token based Parsing.

Namespace for Parser Context classes, these are classes that are used internally by parsers to store their state. This allows parsers to be safely used in a multi-threaded scenario since the parsing of one Graph/Store cannot affect the parsing of another.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Parsing.Events.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Namespace for Event classes which are used to support Event Based parsing of RDF syntaxes

summary.para: Namespace for Token classes which are used to support Token Based parsing of RDF syntaxes
Namespace for Validator classes that can be used to validate various forms of syntax
Namespace for Query Classes which provide Querying capabilities on RDF Graphs

Query capabilities are provided for two forms of Query:
Basic Graph pattern matching which is implemented via the ISelector interface
Sparql Queries
Full SPARQL over local in-memory Triple Stores
Full SPARQL over remote endpoints
Namespace for Aggregate classes which implement Aggregate functions for SPARQL

Contains the classes which model the mapping of SPARQL queries into the SPARQL Algebra. This namespace is a key component of the new Leviathan SPARQL engine introduced in the 0.2.x builds of dotNetRDF
Namespace for classes used in executing CONSTRUCT queries
Namespace for classes which implement algorithms for executing DESCRIBE queries
Namespace containing all the classes related to the execution of expressions in SPARQL queries. Any valid expression should be able to be modelled and executed using these clases.
Namespace containing Expression classes which model functions in SPARQL expressions
Namespace containing classes pertaining to the filtering of the results of SPARQL queries
Namespace containing classes used to apply GROUP BY clauses to SPARQL queries
Namespace for Inference Classes which provide Inferencing capabilities on RDF - these features are currently experimental and may not work as expected.

Classes which implement reasoning must implement the IInferenceEngine interface, these can then be attached to classes which implement the IInferencingTripleStore interface or they can be used to apply inference to any IGraph implementation with the inferred Triples optionally output to a separate Graph.

OWL reasoning currently has extremely limited support, we provide a Pellet client in the Pellet namespace which can be used to connect to a Pellet Server but that currently only provides reasoning on external knowledge bases on the Pellet Server
Namespace which provides a client for interacting with a Pellet Server

Due to Pellet Server being a relatively new product it is currently only possible to reason over external knowledge bases on a Pellet Server and not to use Pellet to reason over in-memory data. As Pellet Server is updated in the future this client will be updated to take advantage of those updates and to eventually provide for in-memory reasoning.
Namespace which provides classes which represent the Services offered by a Pellet Server knowledge base
Namespace containing classes used to order the results of SPARQL queries
Contains the classes which model property paths in SPARQL, they can be used to both represent and evaluate a property path as part of a SPARQL query.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Query.Patterns.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Namespace for Pattern Classes that are used in the Graph and Triple matching process for executing SPARQL queries on IInMemoryQueryableStore objects

summary.para: Namespace for Storage Classes which provide support for using arbitrary backing Stores

There are two main kinds of Store supported:
SQL Database based Stores as backing storage for RDF using classes such as SqlGraph with implementations of the ISqlIOManager interface.
Arbitrary Stores as backing storage using classes such as StoreGraph with implementations of the IGenericIOManager interface.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Storage.Params.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Namespace for Parameter Classes which provide Parameter information to IStoreReader and IStoreWriter implementations

summary.para: Namespace for Translation Classes which provide the ability to translate RDF directly from one format to another
Namespace for performing updates on Triple Stores using SPARQL Update

This is a new part of the API introduced in the 0.3.0 release and adds support for using SPARQL to update Triple Stores. SPARQL Update is part of the new SPARQL 1.1 standard and provides syntax for inserting, modifying and deleting data as well as managing graphs in a store.
Namespace containing classes which model SPARQL Update Commands. These can be used both to represent SPARQL Updates and to execute them over in-memory stores.
Namespaces containing classes which implement the SPARQL Uniform HTTP Protocol for RDF Graph Management
Namespace for Classes designed to aid the deployment of Linked Data, SPARQL Endpoints and other Semantic Web technologies as part of ASP.Net web applications.

As of the 0.3.0 release the ASP.Net support has been heavily rewritten, as opposed to the previous system which required many <appSettings> defining the new system now requires only 1 <appSetting> like so:
<add key="dotNetRDFConfig" value="~/App_Data/config.ttl" />
This setting provides a pointer to an RDF configuration graph that uses the Configuration Vocabulary to express the configuration of HTTP Handlers for your ASP.Net application. We also now provide a command line tool rdfWebDeploy which can be used to automate the testing and deployment of this configuration. See documentation on the Configuration API for more detail. Individual handler documentation gives basic examples of Handler configurations.

Note: As can be seen the old ASP.Net handlers have now all been marked as obsolete, they are left in the library currently to provide compatability with existing applications but we strongly recommend that applications using these migrate to the new Handlers and all new development should use the new Handlers.
Namespace for Configuration classes which are used to load and store the configuration settings for HTTP Handlers provided as part of the Web namespace.
Namespace for Configuration classes which are used to load and store the configuration settings for SPARQL Uniform HTTP Protocol for RDF Graph Management handlers
Namespace for Configuration classes which are used to load and store the configuration settings for SPARQL Query handlers
Namespace for Configuration classes which are used to load and store the configuration settings for handlers which serve resources like Graphs
Namespace for Configuration classes which are used to load and store the configuration settings for SPARQL Servers
Namespace for Configuration classes which are used to load and store the configuration settings for SPARQL Update handlers
Namespace for Writing Classes which provide the means to Serialize RDF Graphs as concrete RDF syntaxes or graphical representations.
Also contains classes that can be used to save Graphs and Triple Stores to arbitrary database backed storage using classes from the Storage namespace.

Namespace for Writer Context classes, these are classes that are used internally by writers to store their state. This allows writers to be safely used in a multi-threaded scenario since the writing of one Graph/Store cannot affect the writing of another.
Namespace for Formatter Classes which can be used to format Triples, Nodes and URIs

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Web.SqlResourceHandler
member.summary: A SQL Resource Handler attempts to retrieve any Uri it is invoked at as a Graph from the underlying Store

remarks.para: This Handler supports only one handler of this type being registered (multiple Handlers can be registered but their configuration will be shared if they get it from the same Web.config file)

Each Handler registered in Web.config may have a prefix for their Configuration variables set by adding a AppSetting key using the type of the handler like so: <add key="VDS.RDF.Web.SqlResourceHandler" value="ABC" /> Then when the Handler at that path is invoked it will look for Configuration variables prefixed with that name.
The Handler supports the same Database Configuration variables as the SparqlHandler and supports the following Configuration variables for itself:

ul.li: LookupMode (Optional) - Sets how the Handler looks up URIs it is invoked with. This should be one of the values from the SQLResourceLookupMode enumeration, see the enumeration documentation for how each mode behaves. Default is Graph

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Web.SqlResourceHandler.ProcessRequest(System.Web.HttpContext)

member.summary: Loads the Handler specific Configuration for this Handler

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Query.Expressions.SparqlExpressionFactory
member.summary: Factory Class for generating Expressions for Sparql Extension Functions

remarks.para: Allows for users of the Library to implement and register Custom Expression Factories which can generate Expressions for their own Extension functions which they wish to use in their SPARQL queries. Custom factories may be globally scoped by registering them with the AddCustomFactory() method or locally by passing them to the three argument constructor of the CreateExpression() method.

member.name: F:VDS.RDF.Query.Expressions.SparqlExpressionFactory._customFactories
member.summary: List of Custom Expression factories
member.remarks: All the standard function libraries (XPath, Leviathan and ARQ) included in dotNetRDF are automatically registered

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Query.Expressions.SparqlExpressionFactory.CreateExpression(System.Uri,System.Collections.Generic.List{VDS.RDF.Query.Expressions.ISparqlExpression})
member.summary: Tries to create an Expression from the given function Uri and list of argument expressions

remarks.para: Uses only the globally scoped custom expression factories

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Query.Expressions.SparqlExpressionFactory.CreateExpression(System.Uri,System.Collections.Generic.List{VDS.RDF.Query.Expressions.ISparqlExpression},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{VDS.RDF.Query.Expressions.ISparqlCustomExpressionFactory})
member.summary: Tries to create an Expression from the given function Uri and list of argument expressions
member.param: Enumeration of locally scoped expression factories to use

remarks.para: Globally scoped custom expression factories are tried first and then any locally scoped expression factories are used

member.summary: Registers a Custom Expression Factory

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Web.SparqlServer
member.summary: HTTP Handler for adding SPARQL Servers to ASP.Net applications - SPARQL Servers provide combined Query, Update and Uniform HTTP Protocol for RDF Graph Management endpoints

remarks.para: Used to create a SPARQL Server with a base URI where any URI under this URI is handled by this Server

For example given a Base URI of http://example.org/server/ then the Handler would treat requests to http://example.org/server/query as SPARQL Query requests, requests to http://example.org/server/update as SPARQL Update requests and requests to any other URL covered by this base URL as SPARQL Uniform HTTP Protocol requests

member.summary: Loads the Handler Configuration

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Web.SparqlServer.UpdateConfig(System.Web.HttpContext)
member.summary: Updates the Handler Configuration

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Web.ProtocolHandler
member.summary: HTTP Handler for adding SPARQL Uniform HTTP Protocol for RDF Graph Management endpoints to ASP.Net applications

remarks.para: Used to create a Protocol endpoint at a specific fixed URL, if you want to allow URIs relative to this URI to be used to refer to Graphs then use the WildcardProtocolHandler instead

member.summary: Loads the Handler Configuration

member.summary: Updates the Handler Configuration

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Update.Protocol.GenericProtocolProcessor
member.summary: A processor for the SPARQL Uniform HTTP Protocol which operates by performing the desired operations on some arbitrary underlying Store for which an IGenericIOManager is available

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Update.Protocol.GenericProtocolProcessor.#ctor(VDS.RDF.Storage.IGenericIOManager)
member.summary: Creates a new Generic Protocol Processor

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Update.Protocol.GenericProtocolProcessor.ProcessGet(System.Web.HttpContext)
member.summary: Processes a GET operation
member.remarks: Implemented by making a call to LoadGraph() on the underlying IGenericIOManager

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Update.Protocol.GenericProtocolProcessor.ProcessPost(System.Web.HttpContext)
member.summary: Processes a POST operation

remarks.para: Warning: If the underlying IGenericIOManager is read-only then this operation returns a 403 Forbidden.
Otherwise this is implemented using UpdateGraph() if updates are supported, if not then the Graph has to be loaded, the POSTed data merged into it and then the Graph is saved again.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Update.Protocol.GenericProtocolProcessor.ProcessPut(System.Web.HttpContext)
member.summary: Processes a PUT operation

remarks.para: Warning: If the underlying IGenericIOManager is read-only then this operation returns a 403 Forbidden.
Implemented by calling SaveGraph() on the underlying manager

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Update.Protocol.GenericProtocolProcessor.ProcessDelete(System.Web.HttpContext)
member.summary: Processes a DELETE operation

remarks.para: Warning: If the underlying IGenericIOManager is read-only then this operation returns a 403 Forbidden.
The delete operation does not explicitly remove the Graph but simply replaces it with an empty Graph

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Parsing.TriXParser
member.summary: Parser for parsing TriX (a named Graph XML format for RDF)

remarks.para: The Default Graph (if any) will be given the special Uri trix:default-graph
TriX permits Graphs to be named with Blank Node IDs, since the library only supports Graphs named with URIs these are converted to URIs of the form trix:local:ID

member.name: F:VDS.RDF.Parsing.TriXParser.DefaultGraphURI
member.summary: Default Graph Uri for default graphs parsed from TriX input

member.name: F:VDS.RDF.Parsing.TriXParser.TriXNamespaceURI
member.summary: Current W3C Namespace Uri for TriX

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.TriXParser.Load(VDS.RDF.ITripleStore,VDS.RDF.Storage.Params.IStoreParams)
member.summary: Loads the named Graphs from the NQuads input into the given Triple Store
member.param: Parameters indicating the Stream to read from

member.summary: Helper method for raising informative standardised Parser Errors
member.param: The Node that is the cause of the Error

member.summary: Helper method used to raise the Warning event if there is an event handler registered

member.summary: Event which Readers can raise when they notice syntax that is ambigious/deprecated etc which can still be parsed

member.summary: A DOM Based event generator for RDF/XML parser that uses System.Xml DOM to parse events

member.summary: Creates a new DOM Based event generator

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.Events.DomBasedEventGenerator.#ctor(System.IO.StreamReader)
member.summary: Creates a new DOM Based event generator

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.Events.DomBasedEventGenerator.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new DOM Based event generator

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.Events.DomBasedEventGenerator.GetAllEvents(VDS.RDF.Parsing.Contexts.RdfXmlParserContext)
member.summary: Gets all events from the XML DOM

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.Events.DomBasedEventGenerator.GenerateEventTree(VDS.RDF.Parsing.Contexts.RdfXmlParserContext,System.Xml.XmlNode)
member.summary: Given an XML Node that is the Root of the RDF/XML section of the Document Tree creates the RootEvent and generates the rest of the Event Tree by recursive calls to the GenerateEvents method
member.param: XML Node that is the Root of the RDF/XML section of the Document Tree

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.Events.DomBasedEventGenerator.GenerateEvents(VDS.RDF.Parsing.Contexts.RdfXmlParserContext,System.Xml.XmlNode,VDS.RDF.Parsing.Events.IRdfXmlEvent)
member.summary: Given an XML Node creates the relevant RDF/XML Events for it and recurses as necessary
member.param: The Node to create Event(s) from
The Parent Node of the given Node

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.Events.DomBasedEventGenerator.IsIgnorableNode(System.Xml.XmlNode)
member.summary: Checks whether a given XML Node can be discarded as it does not have any equivalent Event in the RDF/XML Syntax model
member.returns: True if the Node can be ignored
member.remarks: Comment and Text Nodes are ignored. Text Nodes will actually become Text Events but we'll access the Text using the InnerText property of the Element Nodes instead

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.Events.DomBasedEventGenerator.FlattenEventTree(VDS.RDF.Parsing.Contexts.RdfXmlParserContext,VDS.RDF.Parsing.Events.IRdfXmlEvent,System.Int32)
member.summary: Takes the Event Tree and Flattens it into a Queue as per the rules laid out in the RDF/XML Specification
member.param: Event which is the Root of the Tree (not necessarily a RootEvent)
A numeric value used for Parser Tracing to indicate nesting levels of the Event Tree

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.HashTable`2
member.summary: A Hash Table for use as in-memory storage

remarks.para: Essentially a Dictionary which allows multiple values for each key

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.HashTable`2.#ctor
member.summary: Crestes a new HashTable
member.remarks: Use this constructor if you expect to use this primarily as a dictionary i.e. there is a mostly 1:1 mapping of keys to values with minimal collisions

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.HashTable`2.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new HashTable where the initial capacity at each key is specified
member.remarks: Use this if you expect to use this as a true HashTable i.e. there is a 1:Many mapping of keys to values. Choose a capcity value that seems reasonable for the data you expect to store.

member.summary: Tries to get the actual instance of the given Key and Value from the Collection

member.summary: Adds a Key Value Pair to the Hash Table

member.summary: Nodes must implement an Equals method

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.BaseNode.ToString
member.summary: Nodes must implement a ToString method

remarks.para: Essential for the implementation of GetHashCode to work correctly, Nodes should generate a String representation that is 'unique' as far as that is possible.

Any two Nodes which match via the Equals method (based on strict RDF Specification Equality) should produce the same String representation since Hash Codes are generated by calling GetHashCode on this String

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.BaseNode.ToString(VDS.RDF.Writing.Formatting.INodeFormatter)
member.summary: Gets the String representation of the Node formatted with the given Node formatter

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.BaseNode.ToString(VDS.RDF.Writing.Formatting.INodeFormatter,VDS.RDF.Writing.TripleSegment)
member.summary: Gets the String representation of the Node formatted with the given Node formatter

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.BaseNode.GetHashCode
member.summary: Gets a Hash Code for a Node

remarks.para: Implemented by getting the Hash Code of the result of ToString for a Node prefixed with its Node Type, this is pre-computed for efficiency when a Node is created since Nodes are immutable. See remarks on ToString for more detail.

Since Hash Codes are based on a String representation there is no guarantee of uniqueness though the same Triple will always give the same Hash Code (on a given Platform - see the MSDN Documentation for System.String.GetHashCode() for further details)

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.LiteralNode.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Implementation of the Equals method for Literal Nodes
member.param: Object to compare the Node with
member.remarks:
The default behaviour is for Literal Nodes to be considered equal IFF
Their Language Specifiers are identical (or neither has a Language Specifier)
Their Data Types are identical (or neither has a Data Type)
Their String values are identical
This behaviour can be overridden to use value equality by setting the LiteralEqualityMode option to be Loose if this is more suited to your application.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.LiteralNode.Equals(VDS.RDF.INode)
member.summary: Implementation of the Equals method for Literal Nodes
member.param: Object to compare the Node with
member.remarks:
The default behaviour is for Literal Nodes to be considered equal IFF
Their Language Specifiers are identical (or neither has a Language Specifier)
Their Data Types are identical (or neither has a Data Type)
Their String values are identical
This behaviour can be overridden to use value equality by setting the LiteralEqualityMode option to be Loose if this is more suited to your application.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.LiteralNode.CompareTo(VDS.RDF.LiteralNode)
member.summary: Implementation of Compare To for Literal Nodes
member.remarks: Simply invokes the more general implementation of this method

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.LiteralNode.ToString
member.summary: Gets a String representation of a Literal Node
member.remarks: Gives a value without quotes (as some syntaxes use) with the Data Type/Language Specifier appended using Notation 3 syntax

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.LiteralNode.CompareTo(VDS.RDF.INode)
member.summary: Implementation of CompareTo for Literal Nodes
member.remarks:
Literal Nodes are greater than Blank Nodes, Uri Nodes and Nulls, they are less than Graph Literal Nodes.
Two Literal Nodes are initially compared based upon Data Type, untyped literals are less than typed literals. Two untyped literals are compared purely on lexical value, Language Specifier has no effect on the ordering. This means Literal Nodes are only partially ordered, for example "hello"@en and "hello"@en-us are considered to be the same for ordering purposes though they are different for equality purposes. Datatyped Literals can only be properly ordered if they are one of a small subset of types (Integers, Booleans, Date Times, Strings and URIs). If the datatypes for two Literals are non-matching they are ordered on Datatype Uri, this ensures that each range of Literal Nodes is sorted to some degree. Again this also means that Literals are partially ordered since unknown datatypes will only be sorted based on lexical value and not on actual value.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.ThreadSafeSqlGraph
member.summary: A Thread Safe version of SqlGraph which represents a RDF Graph which is automatically persisted to a SQL based backing store as it is modified
member.threadsafety: Should be safe for almost any concurrent read and write access scenario, internally managed using a ReaderWriterLockSlim. If you encounter any sort of Threading/Concurrency issue please report to the dotNetRDF Bugs Mailing List

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.ThreadSafeGraph
member.summary: A Thread Safe version of the Graph class
member.threadsafety: Should be safe for almost any concurrent read and write access scenario, internally managed using a ReaderWriterLockSlim. If you encounter any sort of Threading/Concurrency issue please report to the dotNetRDF Bugs Mailing List
member.remarks: Performance will be marginally worse than a normal Graph but in multi-threaded scenarios this will likely be offset by the benefits of multi-threading.

member.summary: Gets all the Nodes according to some arbitrary criteria as embodied in a Selector

member.returns: Zero/More Nodes

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.ThreadSafeGraph.GetTriples(VDS.RDF.INode)
member.summary: Gets all the Triples involving the given Node
member.param: The Node to find Triples involving
member.returns: Zero/More Triples

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.ThreadSafeGraph.GetTriples(VDS.RDF.ISelector{VDS.RDF.Triple},System.Collections.Generic.List{VDS.RDF.IDependentSelector{VDS.RDF.Triple}})
member.summary: Gets all Triples which are selected by the final Selector in the Chain (where the results of each Selector are used to initialise the next Selector in the chain and selection applied to the whole Graph each time)
member.param: Selector Class which does the initial Selection
Chain of Dependent Selectors to perform the Selection
member.returns: Zero/More Triples
member.remarks: This method is used to apply a series of Selectors where each filter is applied to the entire Graph but is initialised with the results of the previous Selector in the chain. This means that something eliminated in a given step can potentially be selected by a later Selector in the Chain.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.ThreadSafeGraph.GetTriples(VDS.RDF.ISelector{VDS.RDF.Triple})
member.summary: Gets all the Triples which meet some arbitrary criteria as embodied in a Selector
member.param: Selector class which performs the Selection
member.returns: Zero/More Triple

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.ThreadSafeGraph.GetTriples(System.Collections.Generic.List{VDS.RDF.ISelector{VDS.RDF.Triple}})
member.summary: Gets all Triples which are selected by all the Selectors in the Chain (with the Selectors applied in order to the result set of the previous Selector)
member.param: Chain of Selector Classes to perform the Selection
member.returns: Zero/More Triples
member.remarks: This method is used to apply a series of Selectors where each filters the results of the previous. Each application of a Selector potentially reduces the results set, anything eliminated in a given step cannot possibly be selected by a later Selector in the Chain.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Writing.NQuadsWriter
member.summary: Class for serializing a Triple Store in the NQuads (NTriples plus context) syntax

remarks.para: For efficiency the TriG Writer splits it's writing over several threads (currently 4), these threads share a reference to a Context object which gives Global writing context eg. the target TextWriter being written to. Each thread generates temporary local writing contexts as it goes along, each of these is scoped to writing a specific Graph. Graphs are written to a StringWriter so the output for each Graph is built completely and then written in one go to the TextWriter specified as the target of the writing in the global context.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Parsing.StringParser
member.summary: Static Helper Class which allows raw strings of RDF/SPARQL Results to be parsed directly
member.remarks: The API structure for dotNetRDF means that our IRdfReader classes which are our Parsers only have to support parsing from a file or a stream. For most applications this is fine but there may be occassions when you wish to parse a small fragment of RDF and you don't want to have to put it into a file before you can parse it.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.StringParser.Parse(VDS.RDF.IGraph,System.String,VDS.RDF.IRdfReader)
member.summary: Parses a raw RDF String using the given IRdfReader
member.param: Parser to use to read the data
member.remarks: Use this when you have a raw RDF string and you know the syntax the RDF is in

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.StringParser.Parse(VDS.RDF.IGraph,System.String)
member.summary: Parses a raw RDF String (attempts to auto-detect the format)

remarks.p: Auto-detection is based on testing the string to see if it contains certain keyword constructs which might indicate a particular syntax has been used. This detection may not always be accurate and it may choose a parser which is less expressive than the actual syntax e.g. TurtleParser instead of Notation3Parser as it tends to guess downwards.

For example if you parsed a Notation 3 string that contained Graph Literals but didn't use any of the Notation 3 specific directives like @keywords it would be assumed to be Turtle but then would fail to parse
The auto-detection rules used are as follows:

ol.li: If it contains <?xml and <rdf:RDF then it's most likely RDF/XML
If it contains <html then it's most likely HTML with possibly RDFa embedded

If it contains @prefix or @base then its Turtle/Notation 3
If it contains @keywords, @forall or @forsome then it's Notation 3
Otherwise it's Turtle
If it contains all of a set of terms and symbols that occur in RDF/Json then it's most likely RDF/Json. These terms are "value","type",{,},[ and ]
Otherwise try it as NTriples, NTriples has no real distinctive syntax so hard to test if it's NTriples

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.StringParser.ParseDataset(VDS.RDF.ITripleStore,System.String,VDS.RDF.IStoreReader)
member.summary: Parses a raw RDF Dataset String using the given Parser

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.StringParser.ParseDataset(VDS.RDF.ITripleStore,System.String)
member.summary: Parses a raw RDF Dataset String (attempts to auto-detect the format)

remarks.p: Auto-detection is based on testing the string to see if it contains certain keyword constructs which might indicate a particular syntax has been used. This detection may not always be accurate.

member.summary: Parses a raw SPARQL Results String (attempts to auto-detect the format)

remarks.p: Auto-detection is based on testing the string to see if it contains certain keyword constructs which might indicate a particular syntax has been used. This detection may not always be accurate.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Storage.VirtuosoManager
member.summary: A Manager for accessing the Native Virtuoso Quad Store

remarks.para: This class implements IGenericIOManager allowing it to be used with any of the general classes that support this interface as well as the Virtuoso specific classes.

Although this class takes a Database Name to ensure compatability with any Virtuoso installation (i.e. this allows for the Native Quad Store to be in a non-standard database) generally you should always specify DB as the Database Name parameter

Virtuoso automatically assigns IDs to Blank Nodes input into it, these IDs are not based on the actual Blank Node ID so inputting a Blank Node with the same ID multiple times will result in multiple Nodes being created in Virtuoso. This means that data containing Blank Nodes which is stored to Virtuoso and then retrieved will have different Blank Node IDs to those input. In addition there is no guarentee that when you save a Graph containing Blank Nodes into Virtuoso that retrieving it will give the same Blank Node IDs even if the Graph being saved was originally retrieved from Virtuoso.

You can use a null Uri or an empty String as a Uri to indicate that operations should affect the Default Graph. Where the argument is only a Graph a null BaseUri property indicates that the Graph affects the Default Graph

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Storage.VirtuosoManager.Query(System.String)
member.summary: Executes a SPARQL Query on the native Quad Store

remarks.para: This method will first attempt to parse the query into a SparqlQuery object. If this succeeds then the Query Type can be used to determine how to handle the response.

If the parsing fails then the query will be executed anyway using Virtuoso's SPASQL (SPARQL + SQL) syntax. Parsing can fail because Virtuoso supports various SPARQL extensions which the library does not support. These include things like aggregate functions but also SPARQL Update statements.

If you use an aggregate query which has an Integer, Decimal or Double type result then you will receive a SparqlResultSet containing a single SparqlResult which has contains a binding for a variable named Result which contains a LiteralNode typed to the appropriate datatype.

member.exception: Thrown if an error occurs in making the query

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Storage.VirtuosoManager.Update(System.String)
member.summary: Executes a SPARQL Update on the native Quad Store

remarks.para: This method will first attempt to parse the updat einto a SparqlUpdateCommandSet object. If this succeeds then each command in the command set will be issued to Virtuoso.

If the parsing fails then the update will be executed anyway using Virtuoso's SPASQL (SPARQL + SQL) syntax. Parsing can fail because Virtuoso supports various SPARQL extensions which the library does not support.

member.exception: Thrown if an error occurs in making the update

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.StoreGraph
member.summary: A Graph which represents a Graph of a given Uri retrieved from some arbitrary Store

remarks.para: Any Changes to this Graph locally are persisted to the underlying Storage using a Background Thread. This live persistence is only provided for IGenericIOManager implementations which return true as the value of their UpdateSupported property, otherwise persistence only occurs when the Graph is disposed of by using the SaveGraph method of the manager.
If a process using this class terminates unexpectedly some changes may be lost.

This class is designed to be completely agnostic of it's underlying Storage. The Storage may be SQL Based for example a MicrosoftSqlStoreManager supports IGenericIOManager and can be used with this class though there are specific classes like SqlGraph for SQL backed stores and a separate interface ISqlIOManager dedicated to them. The Storage may equally be some kind of Native RDF Storage such as a VirtuosoManager which stores data in a Native Quad Store or a TalisPlatformConnector which connects to the Talis paltform to access their SaaS solution for RDF Storage.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.WriteOnlyStoreGraph
member.summary: Class for representing an RDF Graph which is automatically stored to some arbitrary Store as it is modified

remarks.para: Designed for situations where you wish to write data to a Graph in the Store where the data being added is not affected by existing data in the Graph.
Unlike it's parent class StoreGraph this class will not automatically load the contents of the existing Graph when instantiated.
Iterating over the Triples/Nodes of this Graph will only return those that have been added to the Graph since its instantiation.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Storage.JosekiConnector
member.summary: Class for connecting to any dataset that can be exposed by Joseki (i.e. any existing Jena model)

remarks.para: Since Joseki can be used to expose practically any type of Jena based model via Sparql and SPARUL endpoints some/all operations may fail depending on the underlying storage model of the Joseki instance. For example not all models support named graphs and not all Joseki instances provide full read/write capabilities.

The Joseki connector permits use in a read-only mode in the event when you only specify a Query Service path to the constructor (or enter null for the Update Service path). When instantiated in read-only mode any attempt to use the SaveGraph or UpdateGraph methods will result in errors and the UpdateSupported property will return false.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Web.WildcardGraphHandler
member.summary: HTTP Handler for serving Graphs in ASP.Net applications

remarks.para: Used to serve a Graph at a base URL with any URL under that being handled by this Handler. The Graph is served to the user in one of their acceptable MIME types if possible, if they don't accept any MIME type we can serve then they get a 406 Not Acceptable

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Web.GraphHandler
member.summary: HTTP Handler for serving Graphs in ASP.Net applications

remarks.para: Used to serve a Graph at a specific fixed URL. The Graph being served to the user in one of their acceptable MIME types if possible, if they don't accept any MIME type we can serve then they get a 406 Not Acceptable
If you have a Graph where you use slash URIs under this URL and you want those URIs to resolve to the same Graph then you should use the WildcardGraphHandler instead

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Configuration.ConfigurationLoader.CheckCircularReference(VDS.RDF.INode,VDS.RDF.INode,System.String)
member.summary: Checks for circular references and throws an error if there is one
member.param: Object you are attempting to load
QName for the property that makes the reference

remarks.para: If the Object you are trying to load and the Object you need to load are equal then this is a circular reference and an error is thrown
The ConfigurationLoader is not currently capable of detecting more subtle circular references

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Configuration.ConfigurationLoader.CreateConfigurationNode(VDS.RDF.IGraph,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a URI Node that refers to some Configuration property/type

remarks.para: The QName provides should be of the form dnr:qname - the dnr prefix will be automatically be considered to be to the Configuration Namespace which is defined by the ConfigurationNamespace constant.
This function uses caching to ensure that URI Nodes aren't needlessly recreated in order to save memory.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Configuration.ConfigurationLoader.ClearCache
member.summary: Clears the Object Loader cache (this is not recommended)

remarks.para: This method should only be invoked in cases where you have attempted to load an object and some error occurred which was external to dotNetRDF e.g. network connectivity problem and

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Configuration.ConfigurationLoader.IsCached(VDS.RDF.IGraph,VDS.RDF.INode)
member.summary: Gets whether the given Object has already been loaded and cached
member.remarks: If this returns true then loading that object again should be essentially instantaneous as it will come from the cache

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Configuration.ConfigurationLoader.LoadObject(VDS.RDF.IGraph,VDS.RDF.INode,System.Type)
member.summary: Loads the Object identified by the given Node as an object of the given type based on information from the Configuration Graph

remarks.para: Callers of this method should be careful to check that the Object returned is of a usable type to them. The Target Type parameter does not guarantee that the return value is of that type it is only used to determine which registered instances of IObjectLoader are potentially capable of creating the desired Object

Callers should also take care that any Objects returned from this method are disposed of when the caller no longer has a use for them as otherwise the reference kept in the cache here will cause the Object to remain in-memory consuming resources

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Configuration.ConfigurationLoader.LoadObject(VDS.RDF.IGraph,VDS.RDF.INode)
member.summary: Loads the Object identified by the given Node based on information from the Configuration Graph

remarks.para: Use this overload when you have a Node which identifies an Object and you don't know what the type of that Object is. This function looks up the dnr:type property for the given Object and then calls the other version of this function providing it with the relevant type information.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Configuration.ConfigurationLoader.GetDefaultType(VDS.RDF.IGraph,VDS.RDF.INode)
member.summary: Attempts to find the Default Type to load an Object as when no explicit dnr:type property has been declared but an rdf:type property has been declared giving a valid Configuration Class

remarks.para: Note: Only some configuration classes have corresponding default types, in general it is recommended that Configuration Graphs should always use the dnr:type property to explicitly state the intended type of an Object

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Configuration.ConfigurationLoader.ResolvePath(System.String)
member.summary: Resolves a Path using the in-use path-resolver

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Configuration.ConfigurationLoader.ResolveAppSetting(VDS.RDF.IGraph,VDS.RDF.INode)
member.summary: Attempts to resolve special <appsettings> URIs into actual values

remarks.para: These special URIs have the form <appsetting:Key> where Key is the key for an appSetting in your applications configuration file. When used these URIs are resolved at load time into the actual values from your configuration file. This allows you to avoid spreading configuration data over multiple files since you can specify things like connection settings in the Application Config file and then simply reference them in the dotNetRDF configuration file.
Warning: This feature is not supported in the Silverlight build

member.name: P:VDS.RDF.Configuration.ConfigurationLoader.PathResolver

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Configuration.UnloadableObject
member.summary: Marker class used in the ConfigurationLoader Object cache to mark objects which are unloadable due to some errors to stop the loader repeatedly trying to load an Object whose configuration is invalid, incomplete or otherwise erroneous.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Update.GenericUpdateProcessor
member.summary: SPARQL Update Processor which processes commands against a generic underlying store represented by an IGenericIOManager implementation

remarks.para: If the provided manager also implements the IUpdateableGenericIOManager interface then the managers native SPARQL Update implementation will be used for the non-type specific calls i.e. ProcessCommand() and ProcessCommandSet(). At all other times the SPARQL Update commands will be processed by approximating their behaviour through calls to SaveGraph(), LoadGraph() and UpdateGraph() in addition to local in-memory manipulation of the data. Some commands such as INSERT and DELETE can only be processed when the manager is also a IQueryableGenericIOManager since they rely on making a query and performing actions based on the results of that query.

The performance of this processor is somewhat dependent on the underlying IGenericIOManager. If the underlying manager supports triple level updates as indicated by the UpdateSupported property then operations can be performed quite efficiently, if this is not the case then any operation which modifies a Graph will need to load the existing Graph from the store, make the modifications locally in-memory and then save the resulting Graph back to the Store

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Update.GenericUpdateProcessor.#ctor(VDS.RDF.Storage.IGenericIOManager)

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.TripleIndexType
member.summary: Possible Triple Index types

remarks.para: Index types are given Integer values with the lowest being the least useful index and the highest being most useful index.

When used to sort Patterns as part of query optimisation the patterns are partially ordered on the usefullness of their index since more useful indexes are considered more likely to return fewer results which will help restrict the query space earlier in the execution process.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.ThreadedSqlTripleStore
member.summary: Class for representing Triple Stores which are automatically stored to a backing SQL Store as it is modified, use this class with large Stores to load them more efficiently
member.remarks: Uses multi-threaded loading to improve initial Load Times

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.ThreadedSqlTripleStore.#ctor(VDS.RDF.Storage.IThreadedSqlIOManager,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Opens a SQL Triple Store using the provided Store Manager, automatically loads all data contained in that Store
member.param: An IThreadedSqlIOManager for your chosen backing SQL Store
The Number of Threads to use for Loading (Default is 8)
Whether loading should be done asynchronously
member.remarks:
If loading is set to Asynchronous then the Graphs will be loaded in a multi-threaded fashion without waiting for them to load before proceeding. This means that code can start working immediately with the Triple Store but that the data contained in it may be incomplete.
The default behaviour is for Synchronous loading which means calling code must wait for the Triple Store to load before it can proceeed.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.ThreadedSqlTripleStore.#ctor(VDS.RDF.Storage.IThreadedSqlIOManager,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Opens a SQL Triple Store using the provided Store Manager, automatically loads all data contained in that Store
member.param: An IThreadedSqlIOManager for your chosen backing SQL Store
Whether loading should be done asynchronously
member.remarks: Uses the Default 8 Threads for Loading

member.summary: Opens a SQL Triple Store using the provided Store Manager, automatically loads all data contained in that Store

The Number of Threads to use for Loading (Default is 8)

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Writing.RdfXmlTreeWriter
member.summary: Class for generating RDF/XML Concrete Syntax

remarks.para: This is a non-streaming Writer which generates an XML DOM Tree and then saves it to a Stream

Since this Writer is non-streaming it may be slower particularly for large Graphs since it has to build the entire XML DOM Tree for the output before it can be saved to disk. While this may be a slight disadvantage this writer is capable of applying more of the RDF/XML syntax compressions than the standard streaming RdfXmlWriter because it can alter the parts of the DOM Tree it has already generated.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Web.RemoteSparqlHandler
member.summary: A HTTP Handler for Sparql Queries where the Sparql Endpoint is provided by some remote Endpoint

remarks.para: Effectively acts as a gateway to a Remote Endpoint, queries are executed against the endpoint and the raw Response Stream received is passed directly back to the Client.
This Handler supports registering the Handler multiple times in one Web application with each able to use its own settings.

Each Handler registered in Web.config may have a prefix for their Configuration variables set by adding a AppSetting key using the virtual path of the handler like so: <add key="/virtualRoot/sparql/" value="ABC" /> Then when the Handler at that path is invoked it will look for Configuration variables prefixed with that name.
The following Configuration Variables are supported in addition to those supported by the BaseSparqlHandler:

ul.li: EndpointURI (Required) - Sets the Remote Sparql Endpoint Uri to which queries will be sent for processing.

SupportsTimeout (Optional) - Sets whether the Remote Endpoint supports specifying a query timeout. Defaults to false (Disabled). If Timeout is not supported then the Handler will simulate the ability to set a Timeout by setting a HTTP Timeout on the HTTP request to the remote endpoint, in this mode partial results behaviour is not supported.
TimeoutField (Optional) - Sets the querystring field name used to specify the timeout when supported, defaults to timeout
SupportsPartialResults (Optional) - Sets whether the Remote Endpoint supports specifying the partial results behaviour in the event of a query timeout. Defaults to false (disabled)
PartialResultsField (Optional) - Sets the querystring field name used to specify the partial results behaviour when supported, defaults to partialResults

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Web.RemoteSparqlHandler.ProcessQuery(System.Web.HttpContext,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String},System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String},System.Int64,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Processes a Query by sending a HTTP Request to a Remote Sparql Endpoint and passing the raw response stream back to the Client
member.remarks: The HTTP Accept header passed to the remote endpoint will be the same Accept header which this Handler receives. If the remote endpoint does content negotiation correctly the Client should get the results in a format they can understand

member.summary: Loads the Configuration for the Handler

member.name: F:VDS.RDF.Query.SparqlEngine.Labyrinth
member.summary: Labyrinth is the original SPARQL engine which is more mature but not fully SPARQL algebra compliant

remarks.para: Due to being obsolete now the Leviathan engine has matured significantly the Labyrinth engine was removed for the Version 0.3.0 release

member.name: F:VDS.RDF.Query.SparqlEngine.Leviathan
member.summary: Leviathan is the newer and more powerful SPARQL engine which is based directly on the SPARQL algebra

remarks.para: From Version 0.3.0 onwards Leviathan is the only SPARQL engine included in the library but the API has been enhanced so end users can introduce their own SPARQL engines or modify parts of the engines behaviour as they desire.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Query.Inference.PelletReasoner
member.summary: A Pellet Reasoner which provides OWL 2 capable reasoning using an external knowledge base from a Pellet Server instance

remarks.para: Note: Currently this reasoner operates only on a external knowledge base and there is currently no way to introduce new knowledge bases/data through the dotNetRDF API

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Query.Inference.IQueryableOwlReasoner
member.summary: Interface for OWL Reasoners which have access to their own SPARQL implementations

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Query.Inference.IOwlReasoner
member.summary: Proposed interface for OWL Reasoners - currently incomplete

remarks.para: Important: This interface is specifically designed so that it does not require the provision of a Graph to methods unless the method does not make sense without taking an IGraph as a parameter. This is because we envisage the use of this interface for connecting to reasoners which have their own access to the data over which they are reasoning and do not need it providing explicitly to them.
Reasoner implementations may throw NotSupportedException for operations they don't support and may throw any other appropriate exceptions as appropriate for operations that encounter errors.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Query.Inference.IOwlReasoner.Add(VDS.RDF.IGraph)
member.summary: Adds a Graph to the reasoners knowledge base

remarks.para: A reasoner may choose to do nothing in this method if that reasoner especially if it operates using some pre-defined, remote or otherwise immutable knowledge base.

member.exception: May be thrown if the Reasoner does not support such an operation

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Query.Inference.IOwlReasoner.Extract(VDS.RDF.IGraph,VDS.RDF.INode)

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Parsing.FileLoader
member.summary: A Class for loading RDF Files into Graphs/Triple Stores

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.FileLoader.Load(VDS.RDF.IGraph,System.String)
member.summary: Loads the contents of the given File into a Graph providing the RDF format can be determined

remarks.para: The FileLoader first attempts to select a RDF Parser by examining the file extension to select the most likely MIME type for the file. This assumes that the file extension corresponds to one of the recognized file extensions for a RDF format the library supports. If this suceeds then a parser is chosen and will be used to attempt to parse the input.

Should this fail then the contents of the file will be read into a String, the StringParser is then used to attempt to parse it. The StringParser uses some simple rules to guess which format the input is likely to be and chooses a parser based on it's guess.
Note: FileLoader will assign the Graph a file Uri prior to attempting Parsing, any Base Uri specified in the RDF contained in the file will override this Uri.
The File Uri assigned will always be an absolute Uri for the File

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.FileLoader.Load(VDS.RDF.IGraph,System.String,VDS.RDF.IRdfReader)
member.summary: Loads the contents of the given File into a Graph using the given RDF Parser

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.FileLoader.Load(VDS.RDF.ITripleStore,System.String)
member.summary: Loads the contents of the given File into a Triple Store providing the RDF dataset format can be determined
member.remarks: The FileLoader attempts to select a Store Parser by examining the file extension to select the most likely MIME type for the file. This assume that the file extension corresponds to one of the recognized file extensions for a RDF dataset format the library supports. If this suceeds then a parser is chosen and used to parse the input file.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Parsing.Notation3Parser
member.summary: Parser for Notation 3 syntax

remarks.para: This is a newly implemented parser as of 11/12/2009 - it was rewritten from scratch in order to remove an issue with Blank Node Handling which could not be solved with the old parser. The code is now around a third the size, parses faster and appears to be bug free so far!
As with the previous Parser @forSome and @forAll directives are in effect ignored and variables are treated simply as QNames in the default namespace.

member.threadsafety: Designed to be Thread Safe - should be able to call Load from multiple threads on different Graphs without issue

member.summary: Represents a union of multiple Triple Collections

remarks.para: The union consists of a Base collection which is the collection that Triples can actually be added to and deleted from and any number of additional collections which are read-only as far as the union is concerned (this does not mean they cannot be altered elsewhere by other code)

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Writing.TriGWriter
member.summary: Class for writing a Triple Store in named Graph TriG syntax to a file/stream

remarks.para: For efficiency the TriG Writer splits it's writing over several threads (currently 4), these threads share a reference to a Context object which gives Global writing context eg. the target TextWriter being written to. Each thread generates temporary local writing contexts as it goes along, each of these is scoped to writing a specific Graph. Graphs are written to a StringWriter so the output for each Graph is built completely and then written in one go to the TextWriter specified as the target of the writing in the global context.

member.threadsafety: Designed to be Thread Safe - should be able to call Save() from several threads with no issue. See Remarks for potential performance impact of this.

member.summary: Creates a new TriG Tokeniser which reads Tokens from the given Stream

member.name: P:VDS.RDF.Parsing.Tokens.NTriplesTokeniser.NQuadsMode
member.summary: Gets/Sets whether the output should be altered slightly to support NQuads parsing

remarks.para: This is used internally to alter how DataTypes get tokenised, normally these are just returned as a UriToken since a Literal can only occur as the Object in NTriples and so if we see a Uri after a Literal it must be it's datatype and not part of another Triple.
In the case of NQuads a UriToken may follow a Literal as the Context of that Triple and not its datatype so it's important to distinguish by using a DataTypeToken instead

member.summary: Helper method for generating Parser Warning Events

member.name: P:VDS.RDF.Writing.Notation3Writer.PrettyPrintMode
member.summary: Gets/Sets whether Pretty Printing is used

member.name: P:VDS.RDF.Writing.Notation3Writer.HighSpeedModePermitted
member.summary: Gets/Sets whether High Speed Write Mode should be allowed

member.name: P:VDS.RDF.Writing.Notation3Writer.CompressionLevel
member.summary: Gets/Sets the Compression Level to be used

remarks.para: If the Compression Level is set to None then High Speed mode will always be used regardless of the input Graph and the HighSpeedMorePermitted property.
If the Compression Level is set to Minimal or above then full Predicate Object lists will be used for Triples.
If the Compression Level is set to More or above then Blank Node Collections and Collection syntax will be used if the Graph contains Triples that can be compressed in that way.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Web.SchemaHandler
member.summary: Handler for serving Schemas mapped to different URIs within your web application

remarks.para: A single instance of the SchemaHandler can be registered per application. It's configuration specifies a number of RDF files which contain Schemas. When a request comes in on a Uri which is mapped to the Handler the Handler will look for that Uri defined as having rdf:type of rdfs:Class or rdf:Property in any of the schemas. If it finds the Uri in one of the schemas it serves that Graph in a format supported by the requesting client.

You register one/more Schemas to the Handler using the following configuration variable. The X in these examples indicate a 1 based index:
SchemaX - Registers the Schema contained in the file with the Handler
For example:
<add key="Schema1" value="MySchema.rdf" /> <add key="Schema2" value="MyOtherSchema.ttl" />
Format of the RDF in each file is determined based upon the file extension.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Web.SchemaHandler.ProcessRequest(System.Web.HttpContext)
member.summary: Processes requests by looking for Schemas that either have the requested Uri as their Base Uri or that have a Class/Property defined in them with that Uri

member.summary: Loads the Schema files specified in the Configuration

member.name: P:VDS.RDF.Web.SchemaHandler.IsReusable
member.summary: Returns that this Handler is reusable

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Web.SparqlHandler
member.summary: A HTTP Handler for Sparql Queries which uses the libraries in-memory Sparql implementation against a SQL backed Store

remarks.p: Warning: This class is now considered obsolete since it is renamed to SqlSparqlHandler from the 0.3.0 release onwards in order to more clearly indicate its function and differentiate it from the other SPARQL Handlers in the API. Please switch your existing code to use SqlSparqlHandler
This Handler supports registering the Handler multiple times in one Web application with each able to use its own settings.

Each Handler registered in Web.config may have a prefix for their Configuration variables set by adding a AppSetting key using the virtual path of the handler like so: <add key="/virtualRoot/sparql/" value="ABC" /> Then when the Handler at that path is invoked it will look for Configuration variables prefixed with that name.
The following Configuration Variables are supported in addition to those supported by the BaseSparqlHandler:

ul.li: DBType (Required for non-Microsoft SQL Server Stores) - Sets the Database Type to use, defaults to Microsoft SQL Server if not set
DBServer (Required) - Sets the Database Server for the underlying Store
DBName (Required) - Sets the Database Name for the underlying Store
DBUser (Required) - Sets the Database Username for the underlying Store
DBPassword (Required) - Sets the Database Password for the underlying Store
DBPort (Optional for Non-Native Virtuoso Stores) - Sets the Database Port for the underlying Store, defaults to the Virtuoso default port of 1111

LoadMode (Optional) - Controls how and when the Handler should load the store into memory. The value of this should be one of the values from SparqlLoadMode, see the API for the enumeration for information on how each mode behaves. Defaults to OnDemand

You can attach one/more Inference Engines to the Store using the following configuration variables. The X in these examples indicate a 1 based index:
ReasonerX (Optional) - Adds an instance of the given IInferenceEngine implementing class specified by a fully qualified type name as a Reasoner to the Store
ReasonerAssemblyX (Optional) - Specifies the name of the assembly that the Reasoner type is located in, if this variable is not specified it is assumed that the Reasoner is a type from dotNetRDF
ReasonerRulesGraphX (Optional) - Specifies the Uri of the Graph that is used to initialise the Reasoner
For example:
<add key="Reasoner1" value="VDS.RDF.Query.Inference.StaticRdfsReasoner" /> <add key="ReasonerRulesGraph1" value="http://example.org/myClassSchema" />

You can also attach one/more Custom Expression Factories to the Store using the following configuration variables. The X in these examples indicate a 1 based index:
ExpressionFactoryX (Optional) - Adds an instance of the given ISparqlCustomExpressionFactory implementing class specified by a fully qualified type name as a Custom Expression Factory to the SPARQL Parser
ExpressionFactoryAssemblyX (Optional) - Specifies the name of the assembly that the Custom Expression Factory type is located in, if this variable is not specified it is assumed that the Factory is a type from dotNetRDF
For example:
<add key="ExpressionFactory1" value="VDS.RDF.Query.Expressions.ArqFunctionFactory" />
A Custom Expression Factory allows you to create a means to define your own custom extension functions and have them executed as part of queries made using this Handler. For details on how to do this take a look at the online documentation

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.INativelyQueryableStore
member.summary: Interface for Triple Stores which can be queried natively i.e. the Stores provide their own Sparql implementations
member.remarks: A Natively Queryable store will typically not load its Graphs and Triples into memory as this is generally unecessary.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.INativelyQueryableStore.ExecuteQuery(System.String)
member.summary: Executes a Sparql Query on the Triple Store
member.remarks: This assumes that the Store has access to some native Sparql query processor on/at the Store which will be used to return the results. Implementations should parse the returned result into a SparqlResultSet or Graph.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Parsing.SparqlQuerySyntax
member.summary: Available Query Syntaxes

member.name: F:VDS.RDF.Parsing.SparqlQuerySyntax.Sparql_1_0
member.summary: Use SPARQL 1.0

member.name: F:VDS.RDF.Parsing.SparqlQuerySyntax.Sparql_1_1
member.summary: Use SPARQL 1.1

member.name: F:VDS.RDF.Parsing.SparqlQuerySyntax.Extended
member.summary: Use the latest SPARQL specification supported by the library (currently SPARQL 1.1) with some extensions

remarks.para: Extensions include the following:

ul.li: LET assignments
Additional aggregates - NMAX, NMIN, MEDIAN and MODE
UNSAID alias for NOT EXISTS
Most of the XPath Function Library for Strings and Numerics supported
Most of the ARQ (Jena's SPARQL engine) Function Library supported

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Parsing.BlockingStreamReader
member.summary: A wrapper to a Stream which does all its Read() and Peek() calls using ReadBlock() to handle slow underlying streams (eg Network Streams)

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.BlockingStreamReader.#ctor(System.IO.StreamReader)
member.summary: Creates a new Blocking Stream Reader from a StreamReader
member.param: Stream Reader to wrap in a Blocking Stream Reader

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.BlockingStreamReader.#ctor(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Creates a new Blocking Stream Reader from a Stream
member.param: Stream to wrap in a Blocking Stream Reader

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.BlockingStreamReader.Read
member.summary: Reads a single character from the input Stream and advances the position in the Stream
member.returns: Next character from the Stream or -1 if at the end of the Stream

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Parsing.BlockingStreamReader.Peek
member.summary: Reads the next character in the input Stream but preserves the position in the Stream
member.returns: Next Character from the Stream or -1 if at the end of the Stream

member.name: P:VDS.RDF.Parsing.BlockingStreamReader.EndOfStream
member.summary: Gets whether the End of the Stream been reached
member.remarks: Since StreamReader.EndOfStream cannot be overridden this class only shadows the property. This means if you use a BlockingStreamReader in a variable typed StreamReader you will hit the end of the Stream one character early which may cause you issues. If you need a BlockingStreamReader then you must ensure to strongly type it as such

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Query.Algebra.AskBgp
member.summary: Represents a BGP which is a set of Triple Patterns

remarks.para: An Ask BGP differs from a BGP in that rather than evaluating each Triple Pattern in turn it evaluates across all Triple Patterns. This is used for ASK queries where we are only concerned with whether a BGP matches and not in the specific solutions
An Ask BGP can only contain concrete Triple Patterns and/or FILTERs and not any of the other specialised Triple Pattern classes

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.VirtuosoTripleStore
member.summary: Class for representing a Virtuoso Native Quad Store and executing queries against it

remarks.para: No data is automatically loaded into this class when it is instantiated, it acts as a queryable view onto the given Virtuoso Store specified by the given VirtuosoManager
Currently Graphs added/removed from this Class do not affect the Virtuoso Store
If you wish to alter the Store you must manipulate the Store directly using the VirtuosoManager or by issuing SPARQL Update commands using the ExecuteUpdate() method.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.VirtuosoTripleStore.#ctor(VDS.RDF.Storage.VirtuosoManager)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of a Virtuoso Triple Store which uses the given VirtuosoManager to connect to a Virtuoso Triple Store
member.param: Manager for the connection to Virtuoso

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.VirtuosoTripleStore.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new Virtuoso Triple Store using the given parameters
member.remarks: Uses the default port of 1111 and assume the Quad Store is in the default database which is DB

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.VirtuosoTripleStore.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new Virtuoso Triple Store using the given parameters

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.VirtuosoTripleStore.ExecuteQuery(System.String)
member.summary: Executes a SPARQL Query on the Triple Store
member.returns: A SparqlResultSet or a Graph if the query is a normal Sparql Query or a null if the query is a Sparql Update command.

remarks.para: This method invokes the Query method of the VirtuosoManager which executes the Sparql query against the store using SPASQL (Sparql+SQL).

You can use this method to issue SPARQL Update commands against the Store if the user account you are using to connect has the relevant privilege SPARQL_UPDATE granted to them, for new development we recommend you use the ExecuteUpdate() method instead.
Warning: In rare cases we have been able to crash Virtuoso by issuing malformed Sparql Update commands to it, this appears to be an issue with Virtuoso.

member.exception: Thrown if the query is malformed or the results cannot be processed
Thrown if accessing Virtuoso fails in some way

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.VirtuosoTripleStore.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes of a Virtuoso Triple Store

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.VirtuosoTripleStore.ExecuteUpdate(System.String)
member.summary: Executes a SPARQL Update on the Virtuoso store

remarks.para: Warning: In rare cases we have been able to crash Virtuoso by issuing malformed Sparql Update commands to it, this appears to be an issue with Virtuoso.

remarks.para: Warning: In rare cases we have been able to crash Virtuoso by issuing malformed Sparql Update commands to it, this appears to be an issue with Virtuoso.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.VirtuosoTripleStore.ExecuteUpdate(VDS.RDF.Update.SparqlUpdateCommandSet)
member.summary: Executes a SPARQL Update on the Virtuoso store

remarks.para: Warning: In rare cases we have been able to crash Virtuoso by issuing malformed Sparql Update commands to it, this appears to be an issue with Virtuoso.

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.TalisTripleStore
member.summary: Class for representing a Talis Platform Store and executing queries against it

remarks.para: No data is automatically loaded into this class when it is instantiated, it acts as a queryable view onto the remote Talis Store specified by the given TalisPlatformConnector
Currently Graphs added/removed from this Class do not affect the Talis Store unless they are TalisGraph instances in which case changes to those Graphs only are persisted to the Talis Store.
If you wish to alter the Store you must use either work exclusively with TalisGraph instances or manipulate the Store directly using the TalisPlatformConnector.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.TalisTripleStore.#ctor(VDS.RDF.Storage.TalisPlatformConnector)
member.summary: Creates a new Talis Triple Store

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.TalisTripleStore.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new Talis Triple Store

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.TalisTripleStore.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new Talis Triple Store
member.remarks: This constructor creates a connection to the Talis platform which does not use authentication, this means that the Store must be world readable in order for queries to be executed.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.TalisTripleStore.ExecuteQuery(System.String)
member.summary: Executes a Sparql Query on the Triple Store
member.remarks: This method invokes the Query method of the TalisPlatformConnector which invokes the Sparql service of the Talis Store specified by the connector. This means that only the Metabox of the Talis Store is queried and therefore any queries containing FROM and FROM NAMED clauses may fail since the Talis API states that these clauses are not supported.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.TalisTripleStore.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes of a Talis Store

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Storage.NonNativeVirtuosoManager
member.summary: A ISqlIOManager implementation which uses a Virtual Database from Virtuoso Universal Server as the backing store

threadsafety.para: Designed to be Thread safe for concurrent read and write access

Note: To ensure correct behaviour for multi-threaded writing you must set the DisableTransactions property to be true. Classes which are designed specifically to do multi-threaded writing will usually set this automatically.
Will only be thread safe for writing if all the classes writing to the database are using a single instance of this Manager.

member.remarks: Since there is no way of knowing what the underlying Database of a Virtual Database in Virtuoso is this Manager cannot automatically create the dotNetRDF Store since it does not know which SQL Setup script to use. You must configure your virtual database yourself before using this Manager to access it.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Storage.NonNativeVirtuosoManager.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Non-Native Virtuoso Manager

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Non-Native Virtuoso Manager
member.remarks: Assumes the Database uses the default port of 1111

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Non-Native Virtuoso Manager
member.remarks: Assumes the Database is on the localhost and uses the default port of 1111

Indicates that the Transaction should be rolled back because something has gone wrong
member.remarks: A Connection and Transaction per Thread are used

member.name: T:VDS.RDF.Query.Algebra.LazyBgp
member.summary: Represents a BGP which is a set of Triple Patterns

remarks.para: A Lazy BGP differs from a BGP in that rather than evaluating each Triple Pattern in turn it evaluates across all Triple Patterns. This is used for queries where we are only want to retrieve a limited number of solutions
A Lazy BGP can only contain concrete Triple Patterns and/or FILTERs and not any of other the specialised Triple Pattern classes

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.QNameOutputMapper.ReduceToQName(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: A Function which attempts to reduce a Uri to a QName
member.param: The Uri to attempt to reduce
The value to output the QName to if possible
member.remarks: This function will return a Boolean indicated whether it succeeded in reducing the Uri to a QName. If it did then the out parameter qname will contain the reduction, otherwise it will be the empty string.

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.QNameOutputMapper.ReduceToQName(System.String,System.String@,System.String@)
member.summary: A Function which attempts to reduce a Uri to a QName and issues a Temporary Namespace if required
member.param: The Uri to attempt to reduce
The value to output the QName to if possible

remarks.para: This function will always returns a possible QName for the URI if the format of the URI permits it. It doesn't guarentee that the QName will be valid for the syntax it is being written to - it is up to implementers of writers to validate the QNames returned.
Where necessary a Temporary Namespace will be issued and the tempNamespace parameter will be set to the prefix of the new temporary namespace

member.summary: Class for generating Turtle Concrete RDF Syntax which provides varying levels of Syntax Compression

member.remarks: See Remarks for this classes CompressionLevel property to see what effect different compression levels have

member.summary: Saves a Graph to the given Stream using Turtle Syntax

member.summary: Generates Output for Triples as a single "s p o." Triple
member.remarks: Used only in High Speed Write Mode

member.summary: Internal Helper method which converts a Collection into Turtle Syntax

member.name: M:VDS.RDF.Writing.CompressingTurtleWriter.RaiseWarning(System.String)
member.summary: Helper method for generating Parser Warning Events

member.name: P:VDS.RDF.Writing.CompressingTurtleWriter.PrettyPrintMode
member.summary: Gets/Sets whether Pretty Printing is used

member.name: P:VDS.RDF.Writing.CompressingTurtleWriter.HighSpeedModePermitted
member.summary: Gets/Sets whether High Speed Write Mode should be allowed

member.name: P:VDS.RDF.Writing.CompressingTurtleWriter.CompressionLevel
member.summary: Gets/Sets the Compression Level to be used

remarks.para: If the Compression Level is set to None then High Speed mode will always be used regardless of the input Graph and the HighSpeedMorePermitted property.
If the Compression Level is set to Minimal or above then full Predicate Object lists will be used for Triples.
If the Compression Level is set to More or above then Blank Node Collections and Collection syntax will be used if the Graph contains Triples that can be compressed in that way.

member.summary: Event which is raised when there is a non-fatal issue with the Graph being written
